item.title: Porting a Verizon My Numbers Number to a full Verizon line
item.description: Note: This assumes that you have a valid destination for the number porting (either a separate phone, or an eSIM phone like a recent iPhone). Backstory/context The call box for an apartment I lived in only accepted destination/resident numbers starting with certain area codes. My phone number did not meet that requirement, so I picked up a temporary second line from Verizon’s My Numbers app. That way, I could just use one phone, instead of buying a separate phone just to answer the door.

item.title: Comcast Business Static IPv6 Setup on a UniFi Security Gateway
item.description: Thank you to mikehanley from the Comcast Business Support Community Forums for the dhcpv6-pd commands. Setting up IPv6 on a Comcast Business account is not straightforward if you are not using Comcast’s combined modem-router. If you are using a UniFi Security Gateway ( SKU: USG), the following steps are necessary to get IPv6 working: Assumptions: Comcast is providing you a /56 subnet for your IPv6 allocation You are using the UniFi web interface to manage your USG through a Cloud Key or Controller installation eth0 is your WAN interface The interactive command-line route In Settings > Networks > WAN, set the WAN interface to DHCPv6 with Prefix Delegation Size to 59 ( why 59 instead of 56) Save the new WAN network settings and wait for the USG to provision.

item.title: Installing VMware ESXi on an Intel J1900
item.description: Attempting to install ESXi on an Intel J1900 results in an error. The boot process freezes on: Relocating modules and starting up the kernel… The fix can be found at: an archive of the original blog post In short, At the ESXi boot screen, press Shift+O to open the boot options prompt. In the boot options line that appears, add the following after a space at the end of the line: ignoreHeadless=TRUE.

item.title: Comcast Business IPv6 Prefix Notes
item.description: original post by John Burwell can be found here Here are my notes from this weekend’s IPv6 prefix exhaustion experiment. Comcast delegates to my router a /59 prefix, instead of a /60. This is unexpected, but it’s okay, because one /59 is two /60s. A two-fer. On the one hand, if you have only one router, this is a limitation; out of the /56 allocated to your account, there are 8 /59s, with only the two /60s per /59.

item.title: Extended Bash History
item.description: link to original stack overflow post First, run the following to establish your extended bash history file: cat ~/.bash_history >> ~/.bash_history_extended I then added the following to my .bashrc: 1 2 3 4 export HISTFILESIZE= export HISTSIZE= export HISTFILE=~/.bash_history_extended PROMPT_COMMAND="history -a; $PROMPT_COMMAND" Remember to run source ~/.bashrc in any running shells/terminal windows to get the latest bash history config established.
